instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2390: What is 820-2390? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1297: What is A1297? A1297 is a model number for a 17 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Early 2009, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011 with EMC 2272, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2390, 820-2610, 820-2849, 820-2914..
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Hi all, first post here! Thanks in advance for all the info shared in this forum and in the Youtube Channel Louis and all. Thanks to discovering this forum I'm thinking about repairing my MBP17" E2009 instead of letting it go.

Let me explain the problem as much as possible to help other people identify similar issues.

[B]MBP SPECS:[/B]
[LIST]
[*]Macbook Pro 17", Early 2009 unit, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. MacBookPro 5,2
[*]Core 2 Duo 2.66GHz
[*]8 GB RAM (2x4 GB CSX DDR3 1066MHz)
[*]Crucial SSD MX200 512GB
[*]SMC version: 1.42f4
[*]Logic Board version: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
[*]Battery is an Apple official replacement one (Apple A1309, 7.3V, 95Wh) that still retains 71% capacity. No battery defects detected by "Battery Monitor" app. Original battery had to be replaced due to cell expansion disturbing the touchpad.
[*]AC charger is an Apple original one, 85W.
[*]MOJAVE 10.14 macOS fully working (thanks to dosdude1.com instructions).
[*]Apps I'm using to locate the problem: HW Monitor, Macs Fan Control.
[/LIST][INDENT]NOTES: same problem happened with macOS 10.11 El Capitan, and also with other A1309 compatible batteries (ANSANOR and other brands, I've tried 3 different ones).[/INDENT] 
[B]THE PROBLEM:[/B]

Short description:

The MBP shuts down randomly, specially when working only with battery, but sometimes (less usual) with the AC charger also shuts down or even without battery (only AC charger).

Details:
[LIST]
[*]When it shuts down, I have to press at least twice the Power button to get re-started. First time is a faulty start almost always (front LED turns on of 1-2 seconds and shuts down again).
[*]Sometimes it does not even arrive to do a full re-start, shuts down during the start up process. Less frequent when powered by AC charger.
[*]When running on battery only it's way way more complicated to turn it on, almost always fails. Measuring Battery voltage during turn on (without AC charger), it's at 8.3V before Power on, and goes down to 7.7V during turn on process, so it does not seem to go so low (nominal is 7.3V). Measuring the CPU voltage does not get lower than 0.98V on the DMM.
[*]When running with the AC charger, if it gets disconnected and remains powered only by the battery, usually shuts down. Time can vary from a couple of seconds up to a few minutes, usually remains more time ON when the CPU is not working hard.
[*]When running without battery, same problem happens, maybe it takes a little bit more time, but ends happening too.
[*]CPU Core Voltages (as per HW Monitor app) vary from 0.780V up to 1.1V (never stays at one voltage level fixed), confirmed by measuring on <CAPACITOR>C1250</CAPACITOR>-<CAPACITOR>C1253</CAPACITOR> with a DMM.
[B]8V back and forth in les than 1 second, is this normal? This voltage fluctuates pretty fast (can go back and forth from 0.78V to 0,9 in less than one second periods).[/B]
[*]CPU temperature arrives at 90ºC (celsius) when reproducing youtube HD videos or other demanding apps. I have Macs Fan Control set to start on CPU1 at 65ºC and max temperature at 80ºC, so they use to be blowing at almost 5000rpm usually.
[*]I've reseted the SMC, NVRAM, etc...
[*]Fans are clean of dust.
[*]Never did a thermal paste renewal.
[/LIST] ¿Any ideas? ¿Can it be the infamous <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>?

Thanks in advance!! I hope this can help other people with similar problems ;)

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Any sign of liquid spill?
<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> should be changed because of its age anyway, so start doing that.
Next, run ASD and look for any errors.
Check for corrosion at <RESISTOR>R2120</RESISTOR>/21.
Also look if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3_RTC</SIGNAL> is stable; inspect <CHIP>U2801</CHIP> area.

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 41676"]Any sign of liquid spill?
<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> should be changed because of its age anyway, so start doing that.
Next, run ASD and look for any errors.
Check for corrosion at <RESISTOR>R2120</RESISTOR>/21.
Also look if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3_RTC</SIGNAL> is stable; inspect <CHIP>U2801</CHIP> area.[/QUOTE]

Thanks for the tips 2informaticos. I've been trying to find the BRD file (I have the SCH) to look for those components, but I'm not able to find it. I guess those components are on the CPU side (<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> for sure isn't it?), so the Logic Board needs to be extracted. Will take it out tomorrow morning. If anyone can share the BRD file of this board, thanks in advance! ;)

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
OK, removed the logic board.

Removed the dust collected in the uP side.

No signs of corrosion or liquid spill. Voltage on <RESISTOR>R2120</RESISTOR>/21 is stable at 3.41V on one side, 3.38V on the other side.

<CHIP>U2801</CHIP> and the Supercap <CAPACITOR>C2800</CAPACITOR> are not populated :O, now I know why my laptop didn't retain the hour when changed batteries.

<CAPACITOR>C2801</CAPACITOR> is populated.

Some voltages I've checked, all stable (at least with a DMM):

<CAPACITOR>C2801</CAPACITOR>: 3.41V (OK, as long as it comes from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_RTC_D</SIGNAL>)

[B]<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>: 1.16V ( bad news it's not 0.31V... will need to keep working to find the real problem!)[/B]

<CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR>: 3.41V (OK from <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL>)
<CAPACITOR>C7292</CAPACITOR>: 3.30V (OK from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL>)

[B]F6905: 16.60V (<SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL>, OK? or should it be 18.5V?)
<CAPACITOR>C7031</CAPACITOR>/37: 16.08V (same as before, not sure, on the SCH says 18.5V but comes from <SIGNAL>DC_IN</SIGNAL>)[/B]

Related with <SIGNAL>PP_BUS_GH3</SIGNAL>, all at 8.43V:
F7040/41: 8.43V (<SIGNAL>PP_BUS_GH3</SIGNAL>)
<CAPACITOR>C7331</CAPACITOR>: 8.43V (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S3_DDRREG</SIGNAL>)
<CAPACITOR>C7133</CAPACITOR>: 8.43V (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_CPU_IMVP</SIGNAL>)
<CAPACITOR>C8930</CAPACITOR>: 8.43V (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_GPU_GPUVCORE</SIGNAL>)
<CAPACITOR>C9540</CAPACITOR>: 8.43V (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0GPU_P1V8P1V1</SIGNAL>)

F4260: 10V (OK)


All seems to be OK except a couple of doubts in [B]bold.[/B]

Any other ideas about where to look? Thanks!!

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Will do it for sure, just to avoid more problems in the future, but the voltage seems pretty stable with the DMM. Will look tomorrow with an oscilloscope too just in case. 

Can it be also that the thermal paste is dry after 9 years, and does not do its work correctly?

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Change thermal paste, of course.
Be sure heatpipe is not broken.
Install some software to check temps on the machine...
Do NOT forget to change <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, with good one.

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message: Thanks! Will bring more news as soon as I do the honework ;)

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Well... got the cap (330uF, 2.5V) and replaced it <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>. Did also the thermal paste job. Everything with care and discharging static... but now after reinstalling all in the chassis, it does not turns ON (not even once) and the board temperature rises noticeable (does not rise too much but noticeable) on the uP and central NVIDIA (<CHIP>U1400</CHIP>) zones.

Tried reseting the SMC and turn it ON with the SMD jumpers (<RESISTOR>R5001</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>) but no luck. The front white led does not make any light, the fans doesn't move, and the LCD does not show anything. Both powering from battery alone, AC alone, or both.

If I check the battery status with the lateral button it shows 100% charge, if I disconnect the battery the LEDs blink one after another.

Voltages I'm reading are:

<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>: 16.04V
F4020: 9.985V (fluctuates between 9.983V-9.990V)
<RESISTOR>R7790</RESISTOR>: 8.4V
<CAPACITOR>C7650</CAPACITOR>: 8.4V
<RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>: 3.396V
<RESISTOR>R5001</RESISTOR>: 2.960V
<CHIP>U7840</CHIP> (pin 6): 3.4V
<RESISTOR>R2120</RESISTOR>: 3.4V
<CAPACITOR>C3101</CAPACITOR>: 1.5V
Fans (pin 1): 5V
<CAPACITOR>C8000</CAPACITOR>: 1.112V

Will keep looking at voltages all around the PCB, but I don't have good feeling... any idea?

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Did you use hot air to change <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>???
Check if is correctly soldered, at least; is bipolar capacitor.

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Hot air to remove and a JBC soldering station (founded) to solder again... can this be the problem?

Checked the voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> after soldering it and it was 1.12V stable (before it was 1.16V).

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> (2.96V) might be slightly lower then its supposed to, I don't think its bad enough to cause issues however.

The fact you have 1.1V at <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S0GPU</SIGNAL> means you're in a S0 state so the device is most likely waiting on the CPU to finish its POST routine or other signals indicating boot can continue.

Is <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S0GPU</SIGNAL> stable? Or does it go on and off? (Power cycle)
Voltage of <SIGNAL>MCP_PS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>? (Is it stable?)

I feel like its possible you've damaged the MCP, have you been careful with heat settings and at least having put on some tape to shield the MCP from direct heat?

EDIT:

I've had many 17" MacBooks from 2009 with this exact same issue though (Random power-off), never been able to resolve most of them. Issues stayed and did not follow any noticeable pattern, it was truly random.

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_S0GPU</SIGNAL> is stable, 1.12V.

<SIGNAL>MCP_PS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> can not check it now, because it's in the uP layer and the PCB is now fitted in the chassis.

But I've found that:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> is 3.3V
[COLOR=#FF0000][B]<SIGNAL>S0_PWR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is 0V[/B][/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>ALL_GFX_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> is 3.3V
And obviously <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0V...

Now let's see why [COLOR=#FF0000][B]<SIGNAL>S0_PWR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is 0V[/B][/COLOR]

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Check first if <RESISTOR>R7892</RESISTOR> is OK.
Next, check all pgood signals involved there.
One of corresponding secondary power supplies doesn't work...

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
Sorry but I don't find <RESISTOR>R7892</RESISTOR> in the schematic (Apple Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> K92.pdf). I have it in the PCB. What's the value for this resistor?

Can this make the processors heat?

threads.title: MBP17" 2009 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Shut Downs randomly
threads.message:
I use <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Cannaregio schematic for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
K92 isn't <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

<RESISTOR>R7892</RESISTOR> is the pull-up resistor (10K) for <SIGNAL>S0_PWR_PGOOD</SIGNAL>.
